dt: {bc}to avoid habitually especially on {d_link|moral|moral:1} or {d_link|practical|practical:1} grounds {bc}{sx|shun||}

pt: {sc}escape{/sc} {sc}avoid{/sc} {sc}evade{/sc} {sc}elude{/sc} {sc}shun{/sc} {sc}eschew{/sc} mean to get away or keep away from something. {sc}escape{/sc} stresses the fact of getting away or being passed by not necessarily through effort or by conscious intent.
{sc}avoid{/sc} stresses forethought and caution in keeping clear of danger or difficulty.
{sc}evade{/sc} implies adroitness, ingenuity, or lack of scruple in escaping or avoiding.

pt.t: {it}evaded{/it} the question by changing the subject

pt: {sc}elude{/sc} implies a slippery or baffling quality in the person or thing that escapes.

pt.t: what she sees in him {it}eludes{/it} me

pt: {sc}shun{/sc} often implies an avoiding as a matter of habitual practice or policy and may imply repugnance or abhorrence.
{sc}eschew{/sc} implies an avoiding or abstaining from as unwise or distasteful.

quotes.t: A fair number of academics {qword}eschew{/qword} the simple title "professor" and call themselves economists, astronomers, historians, philosophers.
Though a doctor with psychiatric training, he {qword}eschewed{/qword} the science that had so enamored earlier child-rearing professionals …
When introduced to a stranger, he {qword}eschewed{/qword} formalities, stuck out a gnarled right hand and responded with a chummy, "Hermann."

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}eschiver{/it} (3rd present {it}eschiu{/it}) of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German {it}sciuhen{/it} to frighten off {ma}{mat|shy|}{/ma}
shortdef: to avoid habitually especially on moral or practical grounds : shun
